article.title: Cosmological perturbation effects on gravitational-wave luminosity distance estimates

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference in the calculation of the initial amplitude of the GW signal in this paper compared to previous work (e.g., [50])?
choices: This paper uses a fully numerical approach, while previous work relied on analytical approximations.
This paper considers only binary black hole mergers, while previous work also included other sources like neutron star mergers.
This paper evaluates the initial amplitude in the Redshift-GW frame, directly linking it to simulations, while previous work used the background frame.
This paper ignores the impact of lensing, which was a significant factor in previous calculations.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which contribution to the luminosity distance correction is generally dominant for higher redshifts (z)?
choices: Gravitational potential effects (SW, ISW, volume, and Shapiro time-delay)

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between the observed average luminosity distance (Dl) and the luminosity distance corrected for perturbations (Dl)?
choices: There is no direct relationship between the two.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why does the inclusion of perturbations in gravitational wave observations pose a greater challenge for future detectors like the Big Bang Observer (BBO)?
choices: BBO will have a much lower sensitivity than current detectors, making it more susceptible to noise from perturbations.
BBO will observe gravitational waves from a much earlier epoch, where the effects of perturbations were significantly stronger.
BBO's increased precision means that the correction to the luminosity distance due to perturbations will be larger than the predicted statistical errors.
BBO's design is fundamentally incompatible with the theoretical framework used to model cosmological perturbations.
